Question: Infinite loop because the iterator doesn't move: :There is a some class which implementing an interface Selector. I should use iterator() in its methods. private class SequenceSelector implements Selector {    private T obj = items.iterator().next();    public boolean end() { return !items.iterator().hasNext(); }    public T current() { return obj; }    public void next() { obj = items.iterator().next(); }}items is a ArrayList. obj is a value in order to save the first sequence member before the first next() using.With a following code the program goes into an infinite loop in which is printed only the first member of sequence. while(!selector.end()) {      System.out.print(selector.current() + " ");      selector.next();}Why does this happens? Though I use next() method, the iterator doesn't move.
Please using this api: Iterator.next.
Answer:
response:
Please answer my code questions using the given API following this format: <<<api>>>: $API
<<<code>>>: $CODE
<<<explanation>>>: $EXPLANATION.
Question: Infinite loop because the iterator doesn't move: :There is a some class which implementing an interface Selector. I should use iterator() in its methods. private class SequenceSelector implements Selector {    private T obj = items.iterator().next();    public boolean end() { return !items.iterator().hasNext(); }    public T current() { return obj; }    public void next() { obj = items.iterator().next(); }}items is a ArrayList. obj is a value in order to save the first sequence member before the first next() using.With a following code the program goes into an infinite loop in which is printed only the first member of sequence. while(!selector.end()) {      System.out.print(selector.current() + " ");      selector.next();}Why does this happens? Though I use next() method, the iterator doesn't move.
Please using this api: Iterator.next.
Answer: <<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: obj = items.iterator().next();
<<<explanation>>>: The problem is that you are creating a new iterator in each call to next(). This means that you are always getting the first element of the list, because you are always starting from the beginning of the list. To fix this, you should create the iterator only once in the constructor of your SequenceSelector class, and then use that iterator in your next() and hasNext() methods.

Fixed code:
```java
private Iterator<T> iter = items.iterator();
private T obj = iter.next();

public boolean end() { 
    return !iter.hasNext(); 
}
public T current() { 
    return obj; 
}
public void next() { 
    if (iter.hasNext()) {
        obj = iter.next();
    }
}
```
In this fixed code, the iterator is created only once at the beginning of the SequenceSelector class. Then, in the next() method, we check if there is a next element before trying to get it. This way, the iterator will move correctly and the program will not enter an infinite loop.
